sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• prior to initiating bicalutamide treatment, measure serum transaminase levels and repeat testing at regular intervals for the first 4 months, and then periodically thereafter; if ALT is greater than 2 times ULN at any time, or if the patient develops jaundice, bicalutamide should be immediately discontinued
  • Metastatic prostate cancer, Stage D2, in combination with a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LHRH) analog: 50 mg ORALLY once daily in conjunction with a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LHRH) analog

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: dosage adjustment not necessary
  • hepatic impairment, mild-to-severe: dosage adjustment not needed; if ALT is greater than 2 times ULN at any time, or if jaundice develops, discontinue immediately
  • hepatotoxicity during treatment: if ALT is greater than 2 times ULN at any time, or if jaundice develops, discontinue immediately
  • hemodialysis: dosage adjustment is not necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Metastatic prostate cancer, Stage D2, in combination with a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LHRH) analog
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Hirsutism

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to bicalutamide or to any component of the product
  • women; use not indicated in women, including women who are or may become pregnant; may cause fetal harm

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hepatotoxicity (eg, hepatitis, hepatic failure), including rare cases of hospitalization or death, has been reported; monitoring recommended; drug discontinuation may be necessary
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including angioedema and urticaria, have been reported
  • reduced glucose tolerance may occur; patients may present with diabetes or patients with preexisting diabetes may lose glycemic control; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP at 1-800-236-9933 or the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Peripheral edema (13%)
  • Dermatologic:Hot sweats (53%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (11%), Constipation (22%), Diarrhea (12%), Nausea (15%)
  • Immunologic:Infectious disease (18%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Backache (25%), Pain in pelvis (21%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (22%)
  • Renal:Hematuria (12%), Nocturia (12%)
  • Respiratory:Dyspnea (13%)
  • Other:Pain (35%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Congestive heart failure (2% up to 5%), Myocardial infarction (2% to less than 5%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis, Hepatotoxicity, Liver failure

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Bicalutamide, a non-steroidal antiandrogen, competitively binds to cytosol androgen receptors in the target tissue to inhibit the action of androgens.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
administer with or without food, at the same time each day

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• serum PSA; periodically or as indicated to assess therapeutic response
  • evidence of prostate tumor response is indicative of efficacy
  • blood glucose; in patients receiving combination therapy with a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone agonist
  • liver function tests, periodically; in hepatically-impaired patients on long-term therapy
  • serum transaminases; baseline, at regular intervals for the first 4 months of therapy, and periodically thereafter
  • serum ALT at first sign or symptom suggestive of liver-dysfunction (nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, and dark urine)

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
BICALUTAMIDE
OVERDOSE: No human data. ADVERSE EFFECTS: hot flashes (49%), general pain (27%), constipation (17%), asthenia (15%) and hypertension (5%) seen with advanced prostate cancer treated patients taking bicalutamide & a LHRH analogue. Effects reported with monotherapy: dizziness, confusion, nausea (3-8%), vomiting (4-7%), rash (6%), and hepatitis (<2%).

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
BICALUTAMIDE
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated
  • Monitoring of patient: Vitals signs; fluid and electrolyte status with significant GI loss. Monitor CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
BICALUTAMIDE
Doses up to 200 mg/day have been well tolerated. A toxic dose has NOT been established.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Counsel patient that drug may cause infertility, at least temporarily. Family planning should be discussed with healthcare provider prior to therapy with drug.
  • This drug may cause gynecomastia, hot flashes, diarrhea, nausea, asthenia, or hepatotoxicity.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of gastrointestinal or rectal hemorrhage, or anemia.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of liver dysfunction, especially hepatic-impaired patients on long-term therapy.
  • Patient should take drug at the same time each day.
